NOVEMBER 17: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks during a meeting of the White House Task Force on the FIFA World Cup 2026 in the Oval Office of the White House on November 17, 2025 in Washington, DC. The task force was created to oversee security, logistics, and federal government support for the 2025 Club World Cup and the 2026 FIFA World Cup, jointly hosted by the United States. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)Comment on this story0CommentShare storySharetopics: MortgageHousing affordabilityUnderwater mortgagesHomebuildersInterest ratesDonald Trump50-year mortgageNegative equity WASHINGTON (TNND) — The Federal Reserve signaled this week that aspiring home buyers expecting more interest-rate relief may have to keep waiting. And that delay is exposing a deeper problem in the housing market: hundreds of thousands of Americans who bought newly built homes over the last few years are already underwater on their mortgages.It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s. (TNND)It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s.How Builders Helped Create a Wave of Underwater MortgagesBeing “underwater” on a mortgage simply means you owe more than your home is currently worth. As Bankrate’s chief financial analyst Greg McBride explains, “you owe more than the current value the asset is worth less than the amount you borrowed”.But according to a new analysis first reported by The Wall Street Journal, many homeowners who purchased newly built houses in 2022–2024 landed in that position almost immediately. That’s because large homebuilders have been offering artificially low mortgage rates, often far below market levels — in exchange for higher home prices.Here’s what WSJ found, based on data from analyst John Comiskey:27% of Lennar’s FHA loans from 2022–2024 are now underwater.18% of D.R. Horton’s FHA loans are underwater.10% of Quicken Loans’ FHA loans (a non-builder lender) are underwater.The playbook works like this: builders advertise mortgage rates around 3.99%, even while the broader market hovered closer to 6.3%. But to make the numbers work, they keep sale prices above what the property might otherwise be worth. Buyers get a lower monthly payment, but at the cost of taking out a loan that’s already near, or above, the home’s actual value.When prices stopped rising, many borrowers slid into negative equity almost immediately.What Happens When You’re Underwater?For homeowners, the consequences are severe, and in some cases, financially immobilizing.You can’t easily sell your home. Selling requires bringing cash to the closing table to cover the gap between the loan balance and the sale price. That can mean writing a check for tens of thousands of dollars.You can’t refinance. Lenders require equity to approve a refi. Without it, homeowners are effectively locked into their existing rates.The risk of default rises. When people owe far more than their home is worth, they’re more likely to walk away, a dynamic that played a major role in the 2008 housing crash, according to Bankrate.It becomes a systemic risk. Large pockets of underwater loans strain lenders, federal backstops, and local housing markets.In short, underwater mortgages trap households and can reverberate far beyond a single borrower.Is a 50-Year Mortgage a Solution, or Another Risk?Into this climate stepped former President Donald Trump, who floated a new idea on Truth Social: 50-year mortgages.Supporters call it an affordability boost. Critics are calling it a “lifetime mortgage.”The Upside: Lower PaymentsLower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks. (TNND)A 50-year mortgage would spread repayment over two extra decades, meaning lower monthly payments.A New York Times analysis found that on a $500,000 home, a borrower could save about $250–$300 a month, around $4,000 a year, with a 50-year loan versus a standard 30-year mortgage.Lower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks.The Downsides: Higher Costs and Bigger RisksThere would be enormous lifetime interest. Using the same NYT example: 30-year mortgage interest: ~$500,00050-year mortgage interest: nearly $900,000You’d pay almost twice the price of the home in interest alone.The National Association of Realtors says the median age of a first-time buyer used to be 36 but is now 40. Add 50 years and they’d be 86 by the time the loan matures.The Bottom LineBuilder-backed mortgages helped more Americans buy homes in a tough market, but often at the cost of pushing them into inflated prices and negative equity. Now, with underwater mortgages spreading across multiple major homebuilders, policymakers are starting to ask whether the industry’s lending incentives need a closer look.Comment with BubblesBE THE FIRST TO COMMENTMeanwhile, Trump’s 50-year mortgage proposal aims to boost affordability but could introduce new long-term risks: massive interest payments, slower equity, and more households vulnerable to downturns.TrendingPenn State study finds cancer cluster in 15 PA countiesA new study out of Penn State is drawing attention to a 15–county stretch of Central Pennsylvania, where melanoma rates in adults over 50 are significantly highOvernight fire destroys multiple homes in Mount CarmelFirefighters spent the early morning hours battling a devastating multi-alarm blaze that tore through a row of homes on South Poplar Street, destroying several \'Anybody can dance\' Famed choreographer and dancer visits old studioFred Tallaksen has lived every dancer’s dream. He’s starred in famous musicals. He’s choreographed for pop stars, commercials, super bowls, and 250 episodes of Fairfield man charged with making terrorist threat, held on $109,000 bondA Fairfield man is facing several charges, including making a terrorist threat.40-year-old Phillip Earl Allen, Jr., is being held in the Jefferson County Jail.NEPA comedy legend, actor and radio announcer Greg Korin dies in Las Vegas at 70Greg Korin, the radio announcer and actor known professionally as Keith Edwards, died unexpectedly Thursday evening at his home in Las Vegas. He was 70. Photo by NICK PROCAYLO /10107351AArticle contentMetro Vancouver’s housing market is cooling — but not by nearly enough to help many families priced out of home ownership. After peaking at around $1.25 million in mid-2022, the price of a typical home has fallen to roughly $1.14 million (as of September).THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR 
Activate your Online Access NowArticle contentThat’s a meaningful drop, yet homes still cost far more than what many families can afford. Without reforms that reduce costs and delays for homebuilders, Metro’s housing crisis will continue.Article contentArticle contentArticle contentTo illustrate the scale of the problem, consider what buying a home in Metro looks like for a middle-income family. According to a new study published by the Fraser Institute, in 2023 (the latest year of comparable data), the annual median after-tax income for a family in Metro was $64,660 while the price of a typical home — \xa0meaning a home of any type (detached, townhouse, condo, etc.) with common characteristics and amenities — was $1.17 million.Article contentThere was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpThanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. Browse here.Article contentThat means a family had to save $238,240 — equal to more than 3 1/2 years of its after-tax income — for a 20 per cent down payment on a typical home.Article contentBut even after this massive down payment, the monthly mortgage payment ($6,052) would cost more than the family’s entire monthly after-tax income.Article contentObviously, for many families, buying a typical home is impossible.Article contentFor those priced out of home ownership, renting has offered little relief. Metro was Canada’s second least-affordable area for renters in 2023 (again, the latest year of comparable data), with the median rental unit costing $1,715 per month — or 31.8 per cent of the median after-tax family income — up from $1,035 (26.3 per cent) a decade earlier in 2014.Article contentArticle contentAnd there’s more bad news. While the recent decline in house prices hasn’t been enough to meaningfully improve affordability, it has made it harder for builders to cover their costs, prompting a steep contraction in homebuilding at a time when the city needs more new homes.Article contentRead More

Granville Street social housing, subject of countless complaints and emergency calls, will close by June 2026 Advertisement 1Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentThis unhealthy dynamic, where price declines weigh heavily on housing construction, is made worse by government policy. Despite hundreds of millions of taxpayer dollars spent on housing initiatives by the federal government, the Eby government and Metro municipalities, including the City of Vancouver, provincial and municipal policies continue to impose needless costs, delays and restrictions on homebuilding.Article contentFor example, municipal approvals for new housing projects take twice as long in Vancouver (7.7 months) as they do in Edmonton (3.4 months) or Regina (3.2 months), owing to a complex and time-consuming permitting process.Advertisement 1This advertisement has not loaded yet.Trending Saskatchewan firm's plan to export through Washington state instead of B.C. has David Eby fuming

Advertisement 2AdvertisementThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentNew highrise developments in Vancouver face municipal fees of $30,900 per unit — compared with $9,300 in Edmonton and $9,000 in Regina. These policies add costs and delays that deter homebuilding, especially when falling prices are already squeezing developer margins.Article contentOf course, some factors remain beyond the control of local policy-makers.Article contentFor example, federal immigration policy, particularly over the last five years, has greatly increased demand for homes in the Lower Mainland and across Canada.Article contentBut here’s a fact — builders would build more homes in Metro, despite falling prices, if not for lengthy approval processes and costly government fees. To help improve housing affordability in Metro, municipalities in the district must remove unnecessary barriers to development.Article contentTegan Hill and Austin Thompson are analysts at the Fraser Institute.Article contentShare this article in your social network

Tumblr Federal budget falls short in addressing housing affordability in Ottawa: real estate boardThe Ottawa Real Estate Board says the federal budget falls short of solving immediate challenges faced by renters and buyers in the city.Author of the article:By Paula Tran Published Nov 09, 2025Last updated Nov 12, 20255 minute read

The initiative aims to supercharge the construction of affordable off-market housing by building them at scale. Photo by Ashley Fraser /PostmediaArticle contentThe Ottawa Real Estate Board says the federal budget provides a good step forward to addressing housing affordability, but falls short of solving immediate supply challenges for first-time homebuyers in the city.THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR 
Activate your Online Access NowArticle contentIn a news release on Nov. 5, the board said the budget did not encourage the construction of low-to-medium-density housing like townhouses, duplexes and low-rise apartments, which are often seen as entry points for first-time homebuyers.Article contentArticle contentArticle contentThis phenomenon is often called “missing middle housing” by advocates, urban planners and architects because these types of residences are under-represented in new housing supply. The majority of housing starts in Ottawa are rental apartments, followed by rowhouses and single-family homes, according to Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation data.Article contentThe Evening CitizenThe Ottawa Citizen’s best journalism, delivered directly to your inbox by 7 p.m. on weekdays.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. Please try againInterested in more newsletters? Browse here.Article content“We definitely need a budget that’s going to be investing in the future of Canadians, and despite the budget being a deficit, it’s something the government has to do,” OREB president Paul Czan said in an interview with the Ottawa Citizen.Article content“We wish that there was more focus on housing in the budget. Giving more attention to supply would have been much more welcome. Ultimately, that’s the biggest problem that we’re still facing.Article content“We need to provide people with lateral movement (in the housing market) into their first home and fill in that missing middle.”Article contentArticle contentCzan’s comments came after Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne tabled Budget 2025 on Nov. 4.Article contentRead More

McDonald's appears ready for ByWard Market return Advertisement 1Story continues belowThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentThe budget proposed $51 billion in funding over 10 years for the Build Communities Strong Fund. The fund is to support infrastructure projects like housing, health care and education.Article contentThe budget also proposed $13 billion in funding over five years for the federal government’s Build Canada Homes initiative, which aims to increase construction of affordable off-market housing by building them at scale. Ottawa was one of six cities initially selected as sites for the development of 4,000 factory-built homes on federal land, with the capacity to scale up to 45,000.Article content“Canada faces a steep housing supply gap that threatens affordability, opportunity and the ability for Canadians to build their lives here at home,” Champagne said in his address presenting the budget to the House of Commons.Advertisement 1This advertisement has not loaded yet.Trending Ottawa Senators' Thomas Chabot returns to injury list after just one game

Advertisement 2AdvertisementThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article contentHe described the budget as the “most ambitious housing plan since the Second World War.”Article contentOttawa Mayor Mark Sutcliffe welcomed the investment in affordable housing, but said he was waiting for more details before commenting further.Article content“Any investments that are being made in infrastructure and housing are very welcome. I’m looking forward to seeing the details on exactly where that will happen,” Sutcliffe said at a news conference following the tabling of the budget.Article content“I’ve had several conversations with the prime minister and with members of his cabinet about the unique opportunities we have in Ottawa to invest in housing, to use federal land to build housing. There’s lots of opportunity there.”Article contentBut Czan said the Build Canada Homes initiative wasn’t enough to solve the affordable housing crisis in Ottawa because it was too focused on non-market rental units.Article contentArticle contentThere needs to be a mix of non-market rental units and affordable homes for first-time homebuyers, he added. The removal of the GST for first-time homebuyers’ purchase of a new build under $1 million is a step in the right direction, he said, but it needs to be coupled with supply-oriented solutions.Article content“If you look at what has been built in all the major cities in Canada over the last five years, it’s been a lot of non-market housing. Being able to provide the supply that’s needed in the market housing category would definitely lead to higher homeownership rates and communities filled with people that are owning their properties,” Czan said.Article contentThe federal budget is expected to go to a vote in the House of Commons on Nov. 17.Article contentFamilies struggling to find affordable homes: reportArticle contentCzan’s analysis also comes as Ottawa families are struggling to find homes they can afford.Article contentArticle contentAccording to a recent survey conducted by Abacus Data for OREB, 82 per cent of Ottawa residents are concerned about the city’s housing situation. Around 67 per cent of those surveyed said local housing was unaffordable, and 50 per cent said they doubted they would ever be able to afford to buy homes in their communities of choice.Article contentSixty-two per cent of respondents also said they were worried that they could lose their homes or rental units if their financial situations suddenly changed.Article contentIt’s not just renters and aspiring homebuyers feeling the pinch.Article contentData from the city’s 2024 Housing Needs Assessment also suggested that thousands of homeowners were experiencing heightened vulnerability in the housing market due to soaring mortgage rates and costs. The proportion of homeowners in Ottawa paying $2,000 or more per month for housing costs nearly tripled from 2006 to 2021 (from 11.5 per cent to 34.2 per cent).Article contentMeanwhile, the percentage of homeowners paying between $1,500 and $1,999 per month dipped from 20.4 per cent in 2006 to 17.8 per cent in 2021.Article content“Families are being priced out,” Czan said.Article contentThere may be some relief coming in the future. A report by the CMHC in July suggested that Ottawa saw an annual increase in average advertised rent prices, but at a slower pace.Article contentAccording to the City of Ottawa’s housing approvals dashboard, 13,662 housing starts were reported between the first quarter of 2023 and the fourth quarter of 2024.Article contentThe CMHC also said 9,000 rental apartments were currently under construction in Ottawa, setting a record for the city.Article contentThe sheer amount of housing approvals, along with slower population growth, will cause rental prices to fall in the future.Article contentBut Czan said more collaboration needed to happen between all levels of government to address the housing affordability crisis and reduce barriers to buying a home.Article contentArticle content“Collaboration amongst all levels of government would be something that would be positively viewed by our association and many other associations in real estate,” he said.Article content“Any measures that could help fill the gap in terms of missing middle housing would definitely be a welcome move for our marketplace.”Article contentHe said, for example, the City of Ottawa should remove development charges because they were a roadblock for developers wanting to build more housing. This leads to lower housing starts in any given year.Article content“Removing those barriers and removing any startup costs and any costs that prevent a barrier to entry ultimately would lead to much more supply being in the market. Ultimately, those costs that are put onto the builder end up getting filtered over to the consumer side of things,” Czan said.Article contentHe also said the city, province and federal governments could work together to provide developers with incentives to build more missing middle housing, especially since officials from all three levels of government were reviewing their financial plans for the next year.Article content“Having a focus on those low-rise apartments and medium-density housing units would definitely be a welcome thing that should be considered in the (city, provincial and federal) budgets,” Czan said.Article contentOur website is your destination for up-to-the-minute news, so make sure to bookmark our homepage and

A report by the CMHC in July suggested that Ottawa saw an annual increase in average advertised rent prices, but at a slower pace.Article contentAccording to the City of Ottawa’s housing approvals dashboard, 13,662 housing starts were reported between the first quarter of 2023 and the fourth quarter of 2024.Article contentThe CMHC also said 9,000 rental apartments were currently under construction in Ottawa, setting a record for the city.Article contentThe sheer amount of housing approvals, along with slower population growth, will cause rental prices to fall in the future.Article contentBut Czan said more collaboration needed to happen between all levels of government to address the housing affordability crisis and reduce barriers to buying a home.Article contentArticle content“Collaboration amongst all levels of government would be something that would be positively viewed by our association and many other associations in real estate,” he said.Article content“Any measures that could help fill the gap in terms of missing middle housing would definitely be a welcome move for our marketplace.”Article contentHe said, for example, the City of Ottawa should remove development charges because they were a roadblock for developers wanting to build more housing. This leads to lower housing starts in any given year.Article content“Removing those barriers and removing any startup costs and any costs that prevent a barrier to entry ultimately would lead to much more supply being in the market. Ultimately, those costs that are put onto the builder end up getting filtered over to the consumer side of things,” Czan said.Article contentHe also said the city, province and federal governments could work together to provide developers with incentives to build more missing middle housing, especially since officials from all three levels of government were reviewing their financial plans for the next year.Article content“Having a focus on those low-rise apartments and medium-density housing units would definitely be a welcome thing that should be considered in the (city, provincial and federal) budgets,” Czan said.Article contentOur website is your destination for up-to-the-minute news, so make sure to bookmark our homepage and

Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.Article contentConditions for buyers are largely improving across Canada, including in Calgary, where a new survey points to lower prices and falling mortgage rates boosting purchasing power. Ratehub.ca released its monthly affordability report, finding improvement from August to September in 10 of the 13 major markets it tracks.THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR 
Activate your Online Access NowArticle contentNotably, Calgary saw the third most substantial improvement in average price, monthly mortgage payment and income required to qualify under the federal stress test rules.Article contentArticle contentArticle content“The biggest impact, though, was on the price side,” says Penelope Graham, mortgage expert with Ratehub.ca.Article contentNoon News RoundupYour weekday lunchtime roundup of curated links, news highlights, analysis and features.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Noon News Roundup will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters? Browse here.Article contentThe average price of a home in Calgary decreased by $4,700 from August to September to reach $567,900. That’s the third largest month-over-month decline among markets, trailing only Canada’s two largest markets.Article contentToronto topped the list with a decline of $9,400 to reach an average price in September of $960,300. In Vancouver, the cost fell $8,300 to about $1.14 million for the average cost of a home.Article contentThe price decline in Calgary was the key driver behind the decrease in the average monthly mortgage payment of $2,908, a drop of $30 from the previous month.Article contentFalling prices also lowered the amount of income to qualify under the federal stress test. It fell $1,100 to $123,200 in September from August to qualify for a rate of 6.47 per cent. That is a slight drop from August when the rate was 6.49 per cent. Both rates are two full percentage points above the posted mortgage rates for a five-year fixed rate used in the study. Borrowers must qualify at that highest threshold to ensure they can afford to pay their mortgage if interest rates rise.Article contentArticle contentAs well, Ratehub.ca calculated income requirements and mortgage payments based on a 10 per cent down payment.Article contentGraham notes that the drop in price and rates “did not really move the affordability dial” for those most affected by affordability challenges, first-time buyers.Article contentYet the study does point to a shift in Calgary’s resale real estate market, she adds.Article content“Calgary had been a seller’s market for quite some time, which started to unwind over the past couple of months,” she says. “That sales-to-new-listings ratio actually dropped” nearly nine percentage points in September. Calgary Real Estate Board statistics from Sept. 30 show the metric was 45 per cent, indicating a market with a balance between supply and demand. Yet the market has been trending toward favouring buyers as the ratio moves closer to 40 per cent, the threshold between a balanced and a buyer’s market, Graham says.Advertisement 1This advertisement has not loaded yet.Trending Braid: UCP performing major surgery on Alberta health care

Advertisement 2AdvertisementThis advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.Article content“As well, supply is over four months, the highest since early 2020,” she says. “That reduces the edge sellers had, and buyers have more negotiation room.”Article contentOverall, the news is favourable for first-time buyers — though limited, says Calgary mortgage broker Cassia Miller, Alberta vice-president for Ratehub.ca.Article content“It’s not a significant change,” she says, noting the $30 reduction overall in average monthly cost.Article contentShe notes the additional cut by the Bank of Canada this month could be another boost, though that reduction is likely already priced into fixed rate mortgages. Miller notes their interest rates are largely determined by the bond market, which often moves in anticipation of central bank moves, among other economic factors.Article contentMiller adds that as of late October rates had already moved, with the lowest for a five-year fixed rate at about 3.79 per cent.Article content“That increases your purchasing power by about $25,000” based on the average price in Calgary, she says, noting that could help some first-time buyers.Article contentYet for the market to see significant growth, the Bank of Canada would likely need to cut rates more, Graham says.Article content“If the overnight lending rate went to two per cent, which we haven’t seen since 2022, that would still be” higher than during the pandemic.Article contentArticle contentShare this article in your social network

Don’t miss our weekly town hall!WATCHClose11Please ensure Javascript is enabled for purposes of website accessibilityFact Check Team: Will Trump\'s 50-year mortgage idea solve or worsen housing affordability?by EMMA WITHROW | Fact Check TeamTue, November 18, 2025 at 7:37 PMUpdated Tue, November 18, 2025 at 10:59 PM4VIEW ALL PHOTOSWASHINGTON, DC - NOVEMBER 17: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks during a meeting of the White House Task Force on the FIFA World Cup 2026 in the Oval Office of the White House on November 17, 2025 in Washington, DC. The task force was created to oversee security, logistics, and federal government support for the 2025 Club World Cup and the 2026 FIFA World Cup, jointly hosted by the United States. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)Comment on this story0CommentShare storySharetopics: MortgageHousing affordabilityUnderwater mortgagesHomebuildersInterest ratesDonald Trump50-year mortgageNegative equity WASHINGTON (TNND) — The Federal Reserve signaled this week that aspiring home buyers expecting more interest-rate relief may have to keep waiting. And that delay is exposing a deeper problem in the housing market: hundreds of thousands of Americans who bought newly built homes over the last few years are already underwater on their mortgages.It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s. (TNND)It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s.How Builders Helped Create a Wave of Underwater MortgagesBeing “underwater” on a mortgage simply means you owe more than your home is currently worth. As Bankrate’s chief financial analyst Greg McBride explains, “you owe more than the current value the asset is worth less than the amount you borrowed”.But according to a new analysis first reported by The Wall Street Journal, many homeowners who purchased newly built houses in 2022–2024 landed in that position almost immediately. That’s because large homebuilders have been offering artificially low mortgage rates, often far below market levels — in exchange for higher home prices.Here’s what WSJ found, based on data from analyst John Comiskey:27% of Lennar’s FHA loans from 2022–2024 are now underwater.18% of D.R. Horton’s FHA loans are underwater.10% of Quicken Loans’ FHA loans (a non-builder lender) are underwater.The playbook works like this: builders advertise mortgage rates around 3.99%, even while the broader market hovered closer to 6.3%. But to make the numbers work, they keep sale prices above what the property might otherwise be worth. Buyers get a lower monthly payment, but at the cost of taking out a loan that’s already near, or above, the home’s actual value.When prices stopped rising, many borrowers slid into negative equity almost immediately.What Happens When You’re Underwater?For homeowners, the consequences are severe, and in some cases, financially immobilizing.You can’t easily sell your home. Selling requires bringing cash to the closing table to cover the gap between the loan balance and the sale price. That can mean writing a check for tens of thousands of dollars.You can’t refinance. Lenders require equity to approve a refi. Without it, homeowners are effectively locked into their existing rates.The risk of default rises. When people owe far more than their home is worth, they’re more likely to walk away, a dynamic that played a major role in the 2008 housing crash, according to Bankrate.It becomes a systemic risk. Large pockets of underwater loans strain lenders, federal backstops, and local housing markets.In short, underwater mortgages trap households and can reverberate far beyond a single borrower.Is a 50-Year Mortgage a Solution, or Another Risk?Into this climate stepped former President Donald Trump, who floated a new idea on Truth Social: 50-year mortgages.Supporters call it an affordability boost. Critics are calling it a “lifetime mortgage.”The Upside: Lower PaymentsLower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks. (TNND)A 50-year mortgage would spread repayment over two extra decades, meaning lower monthly payments.A New York Times analysis found that on a $500,000 home, a borrower could save about $250–$300 a month, around $4,000 a year, with a 50-year loan versus a standard 30-year mortgage.Lower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks.The Downsides: Higher Costs and Bigger RisksThere would be enormous lifetime interest. Using the same NYT example: 30-year mortgage interest: ~$500,00050-year mortgage interest: nearly $900,000You’d pay almost twice the price of the home in interest alone.The National Association of Realtors says the median age of a first-time buyer used to be 36 but is now 40. Add 50 years and they’d be 86 by the time the loan matures.The Bottom LineBuilder-backed mortgages helped more Americans buy homes in a tough market, but often at the cost of pushing them into inflated prices and negative equity. Now, with underwater mortgages spreading across multiple major homebuilders, policymakers are starting to ask whether the industry’s lending incentives need a closer look.Meanwhile, Trump’s 50-year mortgage proposal aims to boost affordability but could introduce new long-term risks: massive interest payments, slower equity, and more households vulnerable to downturns.TrendingWoman taken into custody after police chase throughout multiples counties reached 110 mphA 41-year-old woman was taken into custody after a long high-speed pursuit.Crews battle blaze at Frankenmuth office buildingMultiple fire departments were called into assist the Frankenmuth Fire Department battle a blaze at a commercial office building on Sunday night.MMA fighter, 31, dies after suffering critical injury in final round of matchA mixed martial arts fighter died at the age of 31 after sustaining a critical injury during the final round of a match.Dispensary that recently became a 24-hour business hands out 100 free turkeysGENESEE COUNTY, Mich. – A local business that recently made the decision to become a 24/7 operation spent time on Monday giving back to the community.Gramz CannOver $20,000 in Flint bus passes to be donated for people seeking assistancePeople seeking support from some local non-profits can get a free bus ride during the holiday season. Don’t miss our weekly town hall!WATCHClose11Please ensure Javascript is enabled for purposes of website accessibilityTrump administration tries to break through lock-in effect with \'portable mortgages\'by AUSTIN DENEAN | The National News DeskFri, November 14, 2025 at 12:47 PM4VIEW ALL PHOTOSFILE - A for sale sign stands outside a home on the market in the Alamo Placita neighborhood Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024, in central Denver. (AP Photo/David Zalubowski, File)Comment on this story0CommentShare storySharetopics: Mortgage ratesPortable mortgagesHousing affordabilityLock-in effectHomeownershipHousing supplyMortgage-backed securitiesTariffsWASHINGTON (TNND) — The Trump administration is considering another method to bring down soaring housing costs through mortgage rates that are pricing people out of homeownership and keeping homes from coming onto the market.Federal Housing Finance Agency director Bill Pulte said the administration is “actively evaluating “portable mortgages,” which would allow homebuyers to take their mortgage rate with them when they decide to move. The proposal is a direct bid to confront the so-called “lock-in effect,” where homeowners are unwilling or unable to part with their lower mortgage rate and keeping their home off the market.Many homeowners were able to buy or refinance during the pandemic for ultra-low rates at or below 3%, which cuts hundreds of dollars off a monthly mortgage payment. Rates have been stuck between 6 to 7% for the last several years, creating a barrier for homeowners to put their homes up for sale as they don’t want to take up a new loan at higher rates. More than half of homeowners with a mortgage have a rate below 4%, according to Redfin.Homes are changing hands at the lowest rate in decades in 2025 in a market that has been in a standstill for years as mortgage rates climbed and economic uncertainty set in. A Redfin analysis found only 2.8% of homes in the U.S. have turned over to a new owner in 2025.“Buyers are walking away from deals more often, sometimes due to affordability issues and sometimes because they’re re-evaluating whether now is the right moment to commit,” Redfin head of economic research Chen Zhao said in a release. “Others aren’t even shopping, waiting instead for prices or mortgage rates to come down. On the other side, many sellers are staying put—either because they’re locked into low rates or unwilling to accept offers below expectations.”Allowing people to take their mortgage rate with them to a new property could help boost the supply of existing homes on the market if more homeowners are willing to move with their lower rate.But it could also come with higher list prices as more people enter a market with a limited pool of homes available to buy. Homeowners would also have an advantage on bidding compared to a new buyer who is working with today’s rates with more wiggle room in their budgets.“Anyone able to ‘port’ a 3% mortgage into a new purchase would effectively be bidding with cheap financing in a 6% world. That added purchasing power would push prices up, while renters and mortgage-free owners would still face today’s higher rates—only now with even higher list prices,” Jake Krimmel, a senior economist at Realtor.com, wrote in an analysis.Portable mortgages could also disrupt the U.S. mortgage system and lead to higher rates. Mortgage-backed securities, groups of mortgages that lenders sell to investors, would have their pricing models blown up and create more risk for investors as less loans are paid off early with more homeowners taking them with them when they move.Pulte has also said officials are evaluating a plan to offer 50-year mortgages and how to make mortgages assumable, where homebuyers could take over a seller’s preexisting loan. Assumable mortgages are already available in the U.S. but are rarely used because they require a large cash payment or a second mortgage at current rates.The 50-year mortgage could lower monthly payments by stretching out the term of the loan but would also likely come with higher rates and would ultimately cost buyers more in interest over the life of the loan and make it take longer to build equity.The administration’s efforts to lower housing costs come as an increasing slice of Americans are being priced out of the market altogether with elevated mortgage rates and consistently growing list prices. Home values have climbed significantly compared to before the pandemic for both new and existing homes amid a lack of sufficient supply.A shortage of homes is widely seen as the biggest issue when it comes to tackling housing affordability in the United States. Construction cratered in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis and has struggled to recover to a sufficient level to meet the demand.Housing starts have slumped in 2025 as builders confront cost challenges and a stalled market. Higher rates are also a challenge for construction, which is also impacted by the rising cost of labor and materials.Tariffs have been a double blow for builders, as the uncertainty around them has chilled activity in the housing market and broader economy. Import taxes have also increased the cost of materials used to build homes, making it more expensive for builders to start and complete projects.Tariffs that went into effect last month imposed a 10% tax on all timber and lumber imports, along with a 25% tariff on kitchen cabinet and furniture. Don’t miss our weekly town hall!WATCHClose11Please ensure Javascript is enabled for purposes of website accessibilityFact Check Team: Will Trump\'s 50-year mortgage idea solve or worsen housing affordability?by EMMA WITHROW | Fact Check TeamTue, November 18, 2025 at 7:37 PMUpdated Tue, November 18, 2025 at 10:59 PM4VIEW ALL PHOTOSWASHINGTON, DC - NOVEMBER 17: U.S. President Donald Trump delivers remarks during a meeting of the White House Task Force on the FIFA World Cup 2026 in the Oval Office of the White House on November 17, 2025 in Washington, DC. The task force was created to oversee security, logistics, and federal government support for the 2025 Club World Cup and the 2026 FIFA World Cup, jointly hosted by the United States. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)Comment on this story0CommentShare storySharetopics: MortgageHousing affordabilityUnderwater mortgagesHomebuildersInterest ratesDonald Trump50-year mortgageNegative equity WASHINGTON (TNND) — The Federal Reserve signaled this week that aspiring home buyers expecting more interest-rate relief may have to keep waiting. And that delay is exposing a deeper problem in the housing market: hundreds of thousands of Americans who bought newly built homes over the last few years are already underwater on their mortgages.It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s. (TNND)It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s.How Builders Helped Create a Wave of Underwater MortgagesBeing “underwater” on a mortgage simply means you owe more than your home is currently worth. As Bankrate’s chief financial analyst Greg McBride explains, “you owe more than the current value the asset is worth less than the amount you borrowed”.But according to a new analysis first reported by The Wall Street Journal, many homeowners who purchased newly built houses in 2022–2024 landed in that position almost immediately. That’s because large homebuilders have been offering artificially low mortgage rates, often far below market levels — in exchange for higher home prices.Here’s what WSJ found, based on data from analyst John Comiskey:27% of Lennar’s FHA loans from 2022–2024 are now underwater.18% of D.R. Horton’s FHA loans are underwater.10% of Quicken Loans’ FHA loans (a non-builder lender) are underwater.The playbook works like this: builders advertise mortgage rates around 3.99%, even while the broader market hovered closer to 6.3%. But to make the numbers work, they keep sale prices above what the property might otherwise be worth. Buyers get a lower monthly payment, but at the cost of taking out a loan that’s already near, or above, the home’s actual value.When prices stopped rising, many borrowers slid into negative equity almost immediately.What Happens When You’re Underwater?For homeowners, the consequences are severe, and in some cases, financially immobilizing.You can’t easily sell your home. Selling requires bringing cash to the closing table to cover the gap between the loan balance and the sale price. That can mean writing a check for tens of thousands of dollars.You can’t refinance. Lenders require equity to approve a refi. Without it, homeowners are effectively locked into their existing rates.The risk of default rises. When people owe far more than their home is worth, they’re more likely to walk away, a dynamic that played a major role in the 2008 housing crash, according to Bankrate.It becomes a systemic risk. Large pockets of underwater loans strain lenders, federal backstops, and local housing markets.In short, underwater mortgages trap households and can reverberate far beyond a single borrower.Is a 50-Year Mortgage a Solution, or Another Risk?Into this climate stepped former President Donald Trump, who floated a new idea on Truth Social: 50-year mortgages.Supporters call it an affordability boost. Critics are calling it a “lifetime mortgage.”The Upside: Lower PaymentsLower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks. (TNND)A 50-year mortgage would spread repayment over two extra decades, meaning lower monthly payments.A New York Times analysis found that on a $500,000 home, a borrower could save about $250–$300 a month, around $4,000 a year, with a 50-year loan versus a standard 30-year mortgage.Lower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks.The Downsides: Higher Costs and Bigger RisksThere would be enormous lifetime interest. Using the same NYT example: 30-year mortgage interest: ~$500,00050-year mortgage interest: nearly $900,000You’d pay almost twice the price of the home in interest alone.The National Association of Realtors says the median age of a first-time buyer used to be 36 but is now 40. Add 50 years and they’d be 86 by the time the loan matures.The Bottom LineBuilder-backed mortgages helped more Americans buy homes in a tough market, but often at the cost of pushing them into inflated prices and negative equity. Now, with underwater mortgages spreading across multiple major homebuilders, policymakers are starting to ask whether the industry’s lending incentives need a closer look.Meanwhile, Trump’s 50-year mortgage proposal aims to boost affordability but could introduce new long-term risks: massive interest payments, slower equity, and more households vulnerable to downturns.TrendingCrash victim hit, killed while stepping out of vehicle to investigateA person who left their car after crashing on the Northway was hit and killed.State police say it happened just before 8:15 Sunday evening just south of Exit 11Woman who caused deadly crash while off seizure meds sentenced to prisonA woman who caused a deadly crash while off anti-seizure medication has been sentenced to 1⅓ to four years in prison.Indictment unsealed in the murder of veteran Daniel Frament; suspect pleads not guiltyAn indictment has been unsealed in the homicide investigation surrounding the death of Daniel Frament, the veteran who was killed on the Menands bike trail.Firefighters rescue woman trapped in submerged SUV in Skidmore College pondFirefighters rescued a woman whose vehicle became submerged in a pond on the Skidmore College campus Sunday afternoon.According to Saratoga Springs Fire Dept. And that delay is exposing a deeper problem in the housing market: hundreds of thousands of Americans who bought newly built homes over the last few years are already underwater on their mortgages.It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s. (TNND)It’s a trend analysts say didn’t happen by accident, and the lending practices behind it mirror warning signs from the early 2000s.How Builders Helped Create a Wave of Underwater MortgagesBeing “underwater” on a mortgage simply means you owe more than your home is currently worth. As Bankrate’s chief financial analyst Greg McBride explains, “you owe more than the current value the asset is worth less than the amount you borrowed”.But according to a new analysis first reported by The Wall Street Journal, many homeowners who purchased newly built houses in 2022–2024 landed in that position almost immediately. That’s because large homebuilders have been offering artificially low mortgage rates, often far below market levels — in exchange for higher home prices.Here’s what WSJ found, based on data from analyst John Comiskey:27% of Lennar’s FHA loans from 2022–2024 are now underwater.18% of D.R. Horton’s FHA loans are underwater.10% of Quicken Loans’ FHA loans (a non-builder lender) are underwater.The playbook works like this: builders advertise mortgage rates around 3.99%, even while the broader market hovered closer to 6.3%. But to make the numbers work, they keep sale prices above what the property might otherwise be worth. Buyers get a lower monthly payment, but at the cost of taking out a loan that’s already near, or above, the home’s actual value.When prices stopped rising, many borrowers slid into negative equity almost immediately.What Happens When You’re Underwater?For homeowners, the consequences are severe, and in some cases, financially immobilizing.You can’t easily sell your home. Selling requires bringing cash to the closing table to cover the gap between the loan balance and the sale price. That can mean writing a check for tens of thousands of dollars.You can’t refinance. Lenders require equity to approve a refi. Without it, homeowners are effectively locked into their existing rates.The risk of default rises. When people owe far more than their home is worth, they’re more likely to walk away, a dynamic that played a major role in the 2008 housing crash, according to Bankrate.It becomes a systemic risk. Large pockets of underwater loans strain lenders, federal backstops, and local housing markets.In short, underwater mortgages trap households and can reverberate far beyond a single borrower.Is a 50-Year Mortgage a Solution, or Another Risk?Into this climate stepped former President Donald Trump, who floated a new idea on Truth Social: 50-year mortgages.Supporters call it an affordability boost. Critics are calling it a “lifetime mortgage.”The Upside: Lower PaymentsLower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks. (TNND)A 50-year mortgage would spread repayment over two extra decades, meaning lower monthly payments.A New York Times analysis found that on a $500,000 home, a borrower could save about $250–$300 a month, around $4,000 a year, with a 50-year loan versus a standard 30-year mortgage.Lower payments could help more people qualify, especially first-time buyers who fail debt-to-income checks.The Downsides: Higher Costs and Bigger RisksThere would be enormous lifetime interest. Using the same NYT example: 30-year mortgage interest: ~$500,00050-year mortgage interest: nearly $900,000You’d pay almost twice the price of the home in interest alone.The National Association of Realtors says the median age of a first-time buyer used to be 36 but is now 40. Add 50 years and they’d be 86 by the time the loan matures.The Bottom LineBuilder-backed mortgages helped more Americans buy homes in a tough market, but often at the cost of pushing them into inflated prices and negative equity. Now, with underwater mortgages spreading across multiple major homebuilders, policymakers are starting to ask whether the industry’s lending incentives need a closer look.Comment with BubblesBE THE FIRST TO COMMENTMeanwhile, Trump’s 50-year mortgage proposal aims to boost affordability but could introduce new long-term risks: massive interest payments, slower equity, and more households vulnerable to downturns.Trending1 dead after head-on crash in Florence Co.One person died after a crash on Sunday evening.Darlington home suffers severe damage from \'heavy fire\' A residence in Darlington caught fire leaving severe damages, according toCrews responded to a fire just before 2:30 Monday morning along the 700 block of NortMan taken into custody after alleged death threats to parents at McColl homeDeputies responded to a residence regarding a disturbance involving death threats, according to the Marlboro County Sheriffs OFfice (MCSO).Car overturns near Traces Golf Club in Florence Co. Emergency responders are on scene of an overturned car in Florence County.Around 1:30p.m. on Sunday, West Florence Fire-Rescue, Florence County Emergency MedicVictim lit on fire in horrifying Chicago train attack identifiedThe 26-year old victim set on fire by a career criminal with 72 prior arrests while aboard a Chicago L train last week was identified as Bethany MaGee.NEWS IN PHOTOS:"Local"4Roper St. Francis and MUSC partner to offer enhanced pediatric care for growing population4Wildlife expert explains bald eagle behavior after cat dropped through windshield in NC3Darlington home suffers severe damage from \'heavy fire\' 4North Carolina Gov. Faith leaders call for housing affordability and a repeal of city’s business tax cuts 

 City Councilmember Nicolas O’Rourke (right), Seth Anderson-Oberman (left), and Kadi Ashby (middle) spoke at a press conference Saturday organized by Power Interfaith.  
 Photo by Tommy Tucker   

 Rev. Alisa Lasater Wailoo (right) spoke about the affordability crisis during a press conference on Wednesday Nov. 12.  
 Photo by Tommy Tucker      Previous    Next   

 Posted  Wednesday,  November 19, 2025  12:00 am   
 
by Tommy Tucker 
Faith leaders called for housing affordability and a repeal of the city’s business tax cuts last week during a series of press conferences in neighborhoods across the city including the Northwest. 
Five of the press conferences hosted by POWER Interfaith, a multiracial and multifaith social justice organization, were in Germantown and Mt. Airy. POWER Interfaith’s goal is to pressure City Council into intensifying efforts to address the current housing affordability crisis Philadelphia residents are facing. 
Faith leaders specifically focused on City Council’s June 12 decision to gradually reduce Business Income and Receipt Tax (BIRT), citing potential harm to the city’s working class and most vulnerable residents. 
The BIRT tax is the third-largest source of tax revenue for the city, paid for by business owners or companies engaged in for-profit activity within the City of Philadelphia. The tax is not levied on residents who are not business owners. 
“Cutting business taxes is estimated to cost the city $2.8 billion over 12 years, removing significant dollars from the city budget and forcing residents to shoulder more of the burden,” Jayson Massey, a member of Germantown Friends Meeting, said at a press conference Saturday outside Germantown High School. 
He added, “We are here today in front of the former Germantown High School to show the crisis of affordable housing in Germantown, and also to show that the loss of Germantown High School did not result in usable, safe, and affordable housing for the residents here in Germantown. This neighborhood, with a median income of only $45,727, does not need luxury apartments.” 
The high school building, which closed in 2013, has been converted into an apartment complex called The Annex at Germantown, where rents begin at $1,050 for studio apartments, according to rent.com. 
Along with Germantown and Greene Street Friends Meeting, Northwest faith groups and congregations joining the initiative to lobby for affordable housing include St.Vincent de Paul Catholic Church, Faith Chapel, Face to Face Germantown, Mishkan Shalom synagogue, First United Methodist Church of Germantown (FUMCOG), Second Baptist Church of Germantown, and Unitarian Universalists of Mt. Airy. 

On Wednesday, Nov. 12, FUMCOG co-hosted one of the press conferences, with their senior pastor, the Rev. Alisa Lasater Wailoo, speaking on the issue of affordability. 
“When I arrived here about three years ago, I would say we got about two calls a week for folks in need. We’re now getting about a dozen calls a week, easily,” Wailoo said. “We get calls from young mothers. And it’s not just calls, members of our church, we have seniors who don’t know if they’re going to be able to turn on their heat. We have veterans who wonder about their medical bills. And we have working folks of every race, every gender, every orientation, and background that are struggling.” 
At Saturday’s press conference in front of Germantown High School, several speakers and attendees joined the group of faith and civic leaders including City Councilmember Nicolas O’Rourke and Seth Anderson-Oberman, who ran against Councilmember Cindy Bass in 2023. 
O’Rourke, along with fellow Working Families Party City Councilmember Kendra Brooks, opposed the decision to phase out the BIRT tax. 
“There are very few issues that are as constant as the cost of housing and the terms on which you secure it,” O’Rourke said. “The city’s widest housing gap is the shortage of almost 65,000 units, affordable and available to those with the lowest incomes. That’s a problem.” 
He then discussed what he described as a weakness in Mayor Cherelle Parker’s housing plan. 
“The mayor’s plan for housing, which I have said, and I will say again, does have its fair share of bright spots … But something a number of my colleagues and I have raised was the importance of codifying that most of the plan’s funding goes towards those making the least. Codifying it, not just stating an intention but writing that intent into the letter of the law,” O’Rourke said. “The administration flatly refused to do this a couple of times.” 
He added, “We know there’s no housing gap for luxury apartments. You see them all over the place, and they’re good and empty … Everyone further up the income scale has a unit that’s available to them, though it may not be their dream apartment. It may not be the exact thing that they’re looking for; it may not hit all of their preferences. It may not be the perfect setup, but they can’t afford it. With this in mind, I simply don’t see why we aren’t being clear about working for those who simply don’t have an option that they can afford.” 
Kadi Ashby, the president of the Alden Park Tenants Association, shared her experience as a tenant. When she organized the tenants group early this year, Ashby and her neighbors fought for better maintenance and responsiveness from their building’s management company. 
After months of organizing, she received an email from property management denying her a lease renewal, without providing a reason. 
“I am left unable to afford to move. I’m unable to find a comparable apartment in my neighborhood, and it’s possible that this will force me out of my community, the community that, through all of this, has shown me overwhelming support,” Ashby said. ‘We need all of our city council members to commit to fighting gentrification and the corporate landlords taking over our neighborhoods.” 
One goal of O’Rourke’s office has been to push for better protections for renters, including a bill that would require “good cause” for denying a lease renewal. This effort would protect tenants who attempted to organize from retaliation. 
Anderson-Oberman, who is currently the executive director of the advocacy group Reclaim Philadelphia, ran on a progressive platform, narrowly losing to Bass in the 2023 Democratic primary. On Saturday, he discussed his own family’s struggle with affordability and the actions he believes the city must take to address the housing crisis. 
“The private sector alone, the so-called free market, is never going to solve this crisis. If the private sector were going to build deeply affordable housing for working-class families, they would have done it already,” Anderson-Oberman said. “That’s why our government — city, state, and federal — must step in and build the housing that we actually need. We need public investment. We need government-funded social housing that is mixed-income and permanently affordable.” 
Work ahead 
On Feb. 1, Power Interfaith will host a Citywide Affordability Summit, inviting City Councilmembers to speak with faith leaders, advocates, and residents about a long-term solution to the shortage of affordable housing and other affordability issues. 
Reflecting on the week of press conferences, Meg Cruz, the Northwest organizer for POWER Interfaith, told the Local, “I think it was a super powerful week of action where we saw over 20 of our congregations who were represented at these different press conferences. We had everyday people speaking out about how the affordability crisis impacted them and what the implications of this loss of [BIRT] funding would be like.” 
She added, “This is a crisis that is really escalating at a scale that is impossible for people to withstand within their own means, and the decision to eliminate business taxes makes that worse.” 
Tommy Tucker can be reached at Tommy@Chestnuthilllocal.com.

As CT Senate Takes Up Housing Bill, Carpenters Say Wage Theft Undermines Affordability Goals
by Karla Ciaglo
November 13, 2025, 1:11 pm
 Bluesky LinkedIn Facebook Threads Mastodon Reddit Email X Print
A construction site in Somerville, Massachusetts. Credit: Chris Rycroft / Creative Commons

Hartford, CT – As the Connecticut Senate met Thursday to vote on a sweeping housing package, members of Carpenters Local 326 gathered outside the Legislative Office Building holding banners from job sites where the Department of Labor has issued stop-work orders for payroll violations, unpaid wages, and worker misclassification. Their message to lawmakers was blunt: the state can’t build affordable housing on exploited labor.

“This is happening in all four corners of the state,” said Miguel Fuentes, president of Local 326 and a representative for the North Atlantic States Regional Council of Carpenters. He said out-of-state developers and contractors, from as far as Florida, are profiting from community redevelopment funds and tax abatements while cutting corners on labor.

“They decide they’re going to build these projects on the cheap and not pay workers’ time, not pay unemployment, not pay workers’ comp, and not pay wages,” he said.

The demonstration coincided with the Senate’s special session to advance a housing bill designed to expand the state’s rental stock through zoning incentives, streamlined permitting, and new development subsidies. The House approved the bill Wednesday.\xa0

While the proposal aims to accelerate construction, it contains no provisions addressing wage theft or labor misclassification — an omission unions say could undercut affordability goals before construction begins.

Fuentes said wage theft and misclassification have surged over the past two decades, particularly on publicly supported housing projects.

“We’ve got skilled Connecticut workers ready to go, but contractors bring in out-of-state crews they can exploit. It drains wages and stability from our communities,” he said.

Recent enforcement actions show the pattern. In East Hartford, three principals of ITO Construction and Hotel Renovation Solutions were arrested after investigators found they paid workers in cash and misclassified them on a Fairfield Marriott project.\xa0

In Meriden, subcontractors for A.R. Building Company drew eight stop-work orders after 50 workers went unpaid for nearly two months—roughly $150,000 in stolen wages—before one carpenter was killed on site.

In New Haven, the Labor Department halted work at Spinnaker Real Estate’s 34 Fair Street development for misclassifying employees. In Bridgeport and Hartford, inspectors cited contractors for payroll and insurance violations at major redevelopment projects.

“These are real jobs, real violations, and taxpayers end up footing the bill,” Fuentes said.

A recent advisory from the U.S. Treasury’s Financial Crimes Enforcement Network flagged construction as a high-risk industry for money laundering, tax fraud, and human trafficking. Construction workers, already struggling to make ends meet, are especially vulnerable.

A UC Berkeley Labor Center study found 39% of Connecticut construction-worker families rely on public assistance. Misclassification drains thousands of dollars per worker in lost payroll taxes.

Nationally, between 1.1 and 2.1 million construction workers are misclassified or paid off the books each year — costing more than $12 billion in stolen wages and up to $10 billion in lost tax revenue.

Fuentes said unions have pushed stronger enforcement tools for three sessions, and lawmakers have begun to take notice. Earlier this year, Comptroller Sean Scanlon backed a bill that would allow his office to withhold payments from state contractors found violating wage laws after a 2024 audit uncovered nearly 1,000 wage-theft complaints stalled at the Department of Labor. The Senate approved the measure, but it died without a House vote before the 2025 session ended.

“If there is a company that’s shortchanging workers, we’re gonna shortchange them,” Scanlon reportedly said at the time.\xa0

Union leaders are also pressing for contractor-liability legislation — already in place in 10 states — that would hold general contractors responsible for wage theft committed by subcontractors, suggesting a proposal that would apply to private projects with at least 15 units and include a 30-day window to correct violations without affecting municipalities.

“If we want real affordability, everyone has to play by the rules,” Fuentes said. “Connecticut workers should earn enough to live in the homes they build. Do it right, and we fix problems. Do it wrong, and we multiply them.”

Housing un-affordability hits new high across Rhode Island 

 Data from HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Data from HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for the state of Rhode Island as a whole.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Barrington.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Bristol.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Little Compton.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Portsmouth.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Tiverton.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  

 Local housing affordability data for Warren.  
 HousingWorks RI 2025 Factbook  
       Previous    Next   

 Posted  Wednesday,  October 22, 2025  5:40 pm   
 
By Ethan Hartley 
The cost to affordably buy a median-priced home, or rent a median-priced apartment, now far exceeds the income of the average person looking to do so. And that reality holds true whether you are looking to live in Woonsocket, Little Compton, or anywhere in between.

The 2025 Housing Fact Book, released last week by HousingWorks RI — a research hub based out of Roger Williams University in Bristol that strives to “inform public policy, develop communications strategies, and promote dialogue about the relationship between housing and the state’s economic future and residents’ well-being” — painted the bleakest picture of the state’s affordable housing situation yet.

“In 2024…analysis noted the first time Rhode Islanders required an income of more than $100,000 to affordably buy a home in every Rhode Island municipality,” the report’s executive summary reads. “While that continues to be the case, this year it is now also true that renting—for the first time—requires an income that exceeds the renter median income ($48,434) to affordably rent in every municipality.”

According to the fact book, the cost of a median-priced, single-family home in Rhode Island is now $475,000, requiring a monthly housing payment (on average) of $3,957. That represents a 64 percent increase over 2019, when the median-priced home was $288,792 in the state. For context, a $475,000 home would require a household income of $158,263 to afford. 

The median household income of all Rhode Islanders, per the fact book, is $86,372. For homeowners, the median income was $112,858.

“Based on 2024 median single family home prices, a household would need an annual income close to $130,000 to affordably buy a home in any Rhode Island municipality,” the report reads. “This exceeds the median household income by more than $40,000 and median owner income by more than $17,000.”

The rental situation is no sunnier.

According to the data the average, two-bedroom rental in Rhode Island now costs $2,316 a month, representing a 16 percent increase over 2019, when the average rent was $1,988. A $2,316 per month rent would require a household income of $92,640 to afford without hardship.

The average annual household income for a renter in Rhode Island, meanwhile, is just $48,434.

“Since 2018, wages have grown by less than 30 percent but housing costs in the Ocean State have increased by over 60 percent,” the report reads. “More recently, Rhode Island’s single family home prices have jumped higher and faster than anywhere else in the country and rental increases are currently the steepest in New England.” 

Comparing prices
The most “affordable” place to buy a home in Rhode Island, per the data, is Pawtucket, which would require a $128,635 household income to buy a median-priced home. That is followed by Woonsocket, West Warwick, Central Falls, Warwick, Coventry, East Providence, North Providence, Cranston, and Burrillville to round out the top 10.

Block Island is by far the most expensive community to own a home, requiring a $521,723 annual household income to purchase a median priced home.

The top 10 most expensive communities (excluding Block Island) to buy a median-priced home in Rhode Island are: Jamestown ($357,068 annual income required); Newport ($307,638); Little Compton ($277,754); Narragansett ($265,655); East Greenwich ($264,823); Barrington ($249,379); Middletown ($226,456); Portsmouth ($219,420); North Kingstown ($208,277); and West Greenwich ($205,191).

In terms of East Bay municipalities, East Providence is the most “affordable”, requiring an income of $143,048 to but a median-priced home. That is followed by Tiverton ($149,159); Warren ($174,943); Bristol ($191,440); Portsmouth ($219,420); Barrington ($249,379); and Little Compton ($277,754).

The cheapest place to find a rental apartment, per the data, is Westerly (requiring a $60,320 income to affordably rent a two-bedroom apartment). That is followed by Woonsocket ($62,680); Central Falls ($67,520); Lincoln ($76,440); Pawtucket ($78,080); Bristol and East Greenwich (both $80,080); Newport ($81,960); Smithfield ($82,120); and Coventry ($83,520) to round out the top 10.

East Providence, in contrast to being the seventh-most affordable Rhode Island municipality to buy a home, was found to be the eighth-most expensive place to rent in Rhode Island, requiring an income of $94,800 to afford a two-bedroom apartment. 

Fourteen municipalities, including Barrington and Little Compton, did not have sufficient rental data to be included in this ranking of rental costs. 
One-third of households are cost burdened
The report found that, consistent with prior years, a full one-third of Rhode Island households (142,920 of 436,902 total) are “cost burdened”, meaning they spend more than one-third of their total annual income on housing costs. In the most recent data, they found that 44 percent of those cost-burdened households (62,237) are severely cost-burdened, meaning that they spend over 50 percent of their annual income on housing.

These figures get worse when separated by ethnicity. More than a third of Black home owners (35 percent) and Hispanic homeowners (39 percent) are cost-burdened, compared to 24 percent of white homeowners and 19 percent of Asian homeowners. 

The data also reveals that it is not just young people looking for homes that aren’t making enough money. Nearly 30 percent of the more than 60,000 severely cost-burdened households in Rhode Island (18,475) are mortgaged homeowners with incomes under $68,000, commonly elderly people on fixed incomes. 

The majority of severely cost-burdened households (37,466) are those without a mortgage, and renters making annual household incomes less than $40,000. 

Housing production is up, but more investment needed
While the report recognizes that the Rhode Island legislature has spent the last three years passing numerous laws intended to boost housing production in the state in the hopes to better meet demand and drive down costs, the data also revealed that more work, and monetary investment, is needed.

On the good side, the report states that more than $330 million in pandemic-related funding went to the creation of more than 1,835 new affordable homes, enabling 1,672 people to become new homeowners, and the creation of 1,400 shelter beds for those experiencing homelessness. 

However, the report found that overall, more than 80 percent of the state’s $44 million in efforts to bolster affordable housing for the federal program year that ended on June 30, 2024 came from federal funding sources, creating a precarious situation when it comes to the future availability of those funds.

“With…the uncertainty of future federal funding, it is crucial that state investments include permanent streams of revenue to continue forward momentum,” the report states. 

It goes on to praise the recent creation of a five-year pilot program, infused with $30 million initially, to create a low-income housing state tax credit program, as well as the $120 million state housing bond that passed in the 2024 election.

The report showed that, while the state saw 2,818 total housing permits issued in 2024 (a 15 percent increase over 2023), a large chunk of that was due to a 25 percent increase in single-family home permits. 

Multifamily home permits, which do more to address the widespread need of housing, only increased by 3 percent in the same span. Furthermore, the state saw 130 fewer multifamily permits in Q1 of 2025 than in Q1 of 2024.

Accessory dwelling units (ADUs), which since late 2024 have been made easier to be built by-right by homeowners to provide additional housing units on existing parcels, showed a significant albeit still small increase in the overall number of permits — from 28 in 2023, to 163 in 2024. 

Overall, the report showed that only eight municipalities in Rhode Island have achieved the state’s goal for each city and town to have 10 percent of its total housing stock be deemed “affordable”. Those municipalities are: Burrillville (10.19 percent); Central Falls (17.76 percent); East Providence (10.64 percent); Newport (17.27 percent); Pawtucket (10.41 percent); Providence (16.59 percent); West Warwick (10.6 percent); and Woonsocket (17.09 percent).

['A new HousingWire Data deep-dive confirms widening affordability gaps and rising inventory in previously constrained markets — as well as strong regional patterns that favor the South for balance and the Midwest for price relief.
Pittsburgh continues to stand out as the nation’s most affordable major metro, with a median list price of $240,000. Its price-per-square-foot of $167.55 also positions it well below national averages.
Despite that affordability, the market is far from sluggish.
Pittsburgh posts a 35.5 Market Action Index (MAI), placing it in seller-leaning territory as the market carries just 2.5 months of inventory.
MAI is HousingWire Data’s proprietary measure of market heat that ranges from 0–100 and gauges the balance between supply and demand.
Deb Reddick, a Realtor at Pittsburgh-based REMAX 360 Realty, noted that demand is supported not just by low prices, but by strong fundamentals in the region.
“One of the reasons people move here is we have excellent medical facilities, that makes people want to be here and it makes them feel like they’re in good hands,” she said. “We’re not seeing prices climb as high here as other places, and it’s hard to point to one or a few reasons why that is.
“We’ve had a lot of building and improvement lately, too. The roads make it so if you live just outside of downtown, it’s not hard to get in. It’s all tied together nicely.”
The metro also reports a strong 10.2% weekly absorption rate — the highest among key metros reviewed — and a 4.4% year-over-year price gain, signaling healthy and sustainable appreciation.
Homes average 63 days on market, and nearly half of active listings take price cuts, yet sellers still maintain leverage due to tight supply.
Reddick adds that Pittsburgh’s growth has remained measured in part because home values started from a lower base.
“Well, I think, honestly, they were lower to begin with, and with them climbing they’re not keeping in line with the other cities,” she said. “We’ve also had a lot of new building and construction — a lot of new high rises and condos.”
Austin’s inventory surge
Austin, Texas, once among the most supply-constrained markets in the country, now posts one of the strongest inventory totals in the analysis with 10,867 active listings.
With 505 new listings added each week, Austin’s supply pipeline remains robust.
Inventory is up 19.1% year-over-year — the sharpest increase among major metros.
Despite a recent 5.1% price dip, the market operates at a balanced MAI of 33.1, suggesting buyers have more choice than they did during the pandemic boom but still face competitive conditions.
Matt Menard, broker-owner at ERA Real Estate Experts in Austin, notes how stark the shift has been from pandemic-era scarcity
“We were certainly one of the hottest markets in the country during COVID, and during that period of time, we had an inordinate amount of growth and appreciation,” he said. “There was a time when our inventory levels were about a half a month or less, and then now we’re pushing five months of inventory and 80-plus days on the market.”
Homes average 84 days on market and price-per-square-foot sits at $225.03.
Menard emphasized that despite the cooling, the market remains active and offers opportunity.
“We’re still seeing a relatively good sales pace,” he said. “Inventory is just hanging out there. The number of sales are still relatively strong. We’re just seeing properties take a little bit longer to sell, and I think for buyers, it represents an incredible environment.
“It’s a chance to buy when the market is much more forgiving. I’m telling buyers that it’s kind of like a Black Friday sale this quarter, and people are going to look back in a year or two and wish they had bought real estate during this time period.”
Cape Coral–Fort Myers tops in supply
Cape Coral–Fort Myers stands out for its unusually high inventory relative to demand conditions.
With 7,910 active listings — the 15th highest total nationally — the market is firmly in buyer-friendly territory at an MAI of 27.0.
Its 4.6 months of inventory is the highest among the major markets reviewed, giving buyers substantially more leverage than in tight coastal metros.
Year-over-year prices have adjusted downward by 6.4%, and homes stay on the market for an average of 119 days, one of the longest timelines.
West Coast, Midwest affordability opposites
Los Angeles remains the least affordable major metro in the country with a median price of $1,429,500 — roughly 703% higher than Pittsburgh. The metro commands an extraordinary $703.19 price-per-square-foot, more than doubling most markets analyzed.
Despite slight price softening, Los Angeles posts a strong seller MAI of 42.8 and has the tightest inventory conditions among major metros at just 1.8 months of supply.
HousingWire Data confirms that 10 of the top 25 most affordable metros are located in the Midwest, more than any other region.
The region posts the lowest average median price nationally at $311,937 and the strongest market activity with an average MAI of 39.3.
Metros such as Danville, Ill.; Decatur, Ill.; Saginaw, Mich.; and Peoria, Ill. all rank among the country’s most affordable, with many median prices falling below $170,000.
Finding balance in the South
The South — which contains 129 metros in the HousingWire’s data — continues to deliver the strongest combination of affordability and market balance.
The region’s average median price of $362,244 ranks as the second most affordable nationwide, and its average MAI of 32.3 suggests generally buyer-friendly conditions.
Notable performers include Oklahoma City, Little Rock, Ark.; Austin, and Nashville, Tenn., — all of which maintain market balance while offering comparatively lower prices than coastal peers.
